entry.title: SAC seamless planning: Model design principles - compared to SAP BW
entry.content:
After years of developing planning solutions with SAP BW Integrated Planning and BPC, I recently completed a SAC Planning project with seamless planning. Coming from a BW IP/BPC background, I initially tried to replicate familiar structures in SAC. But I quickly realized that SACâ€™s flexibility requires a different mindset, starting with model design and granularity.

In this first blog post, Iâ€™ll share model design decisions, and practical tips for BW developers moving to SAC Planning. This blog post shall also help developers without BW background by highlighting the restrictions of certain functionalities in SAC. Finally, I also want to show you the potential additional value of seamless planning for your planning project.

1. SAC vs. SAP BW modelling: general background information

In SAC, the new model is a mixture of InfoCube-like and a direct-update planning ADSO in BW. All characteristics are keys (InfoCube-like), but there is only an active table (direct-update). Furthermore, measures in SAC models cannot be of a text/characteristic type. So,

  • there are no requests, no chance to roll back
  • no inherited delta mechanism
  • no characteristic as key figure.

But SAC models come with a Standard data audit functionality, that works out of the box (except for import jobs). Because of the missing requests in SAC, planning functions should be kept simple.

2. Model Design: SAC is not BW

When designing planning solutions in SAC, I recommend you to break down planning requirements across multiple models. In SAP BW, developers were required to create composite providers and aggregation levels (and input enabled queries) on top of ADSOs to structure planning logic. SAC does not have those intermediate layers, which can accelerate development. But this simplicity also introduces challenges when trying to consolidate everything into a single model.

Here are a few examples:

  • Any data entry creates an edit version. If multiple planning scenarios share one model, SAC shows the â€œPublish Dataâ€ banner across all stories when you edit plan data in one story.

  • The SAC Excel Add-In allows end users to plan on ad-hoc created tables, which can be convenient for flexibility. However, this becomes significantly more critical when SAC models are large and complex. In such cases, ad-hoc planning can bypass frontend validations (for instance, javascript logic in stories), leading to inconsistencies and governance challenges (check comments here Ability to disable planning option in SAC Cloud excel add-in centrally by admin).
  • Upload jobs in SAC cannot derive master data automatically. In huge models, this often leads to wide files with many columns.
  • Data validations are less robust than characteristic relationships in BW. They must be handled manually in Data Actions and carefully considered during story design, since SAC still allows "unassigned" values even when validations are defined.
  • Data point comments are more fragile. Because they depend on the full navigation state, they can be lost more easily in huge models.

These limitations highlight the need to rethink model design. Instead of treating an SAC planning model like a BW ADSO, itâ€™s more accurate to compare it to an aggregation level or even an input enabled query. It's a layer tailored to specific planning logic.

3. How does seamless planning help?

Seamless planning let's you expose your fact and dimension tables to Datasphere. Hence, you can bring together the data of your different models more easily for reporting purposes instead of having a lot of cross model copies in native SAC.

You can also

  • add SQLscript logic,
  • enrich your plan data with Datasphere tables for configuration/customizing (multiple keys and characteristics as non-key fields),
  • or leveraging public dimensions exposed from SAC (single key).

The results can be consumed

  • via real-time reporting (Datasphere Analytic Models)
  • or via import jobs to SAC models.

4. What's next?

With the Q4/2025 update, seamless planning shall become bidirectional, meaning that the View data in Datasphere can be added to SAC models as read-only version. This update will make Datasphere data better accessible. It will support direct consumption of Datasphere fact data in planning models, which will let you have a single planning enabled table with real-time reference data from other planning models.

Summary

  • Model design matters: Avoid putting all planning scenarios into one model. SAC lacks BWâ€™s aggregation layer, so splitting models improves performance and governance. 
  • Seamless Planning currently focuses on exposing SAC fact and dimension tables to SAP Datasphere, enabling integrated reporting and SQLScript-based logic. It will help you implementing a federated planning landscape in SAC.
  • Always keep the Roadmap in mind: By Q4/2025, SAC will support direct consumption of Datasphere fact data in planning models, reducing reliance on import jobs and enabling real-time integration in planning enabled crosstabs.

entry.title: SAP Datasphere News in September
entry.content:
SAP Datasphere News in September

Another month with two nice new release deliveries âœ¨

Learn more in my short top features video in September 2025 on YouTube ğŸ“º

In addition, explore the latest updates in our community news blogs and more.

â€ƒ

My top features in September

 

Input Parameters in Task Chains and Transformation Flows

You can now define input parameters on the task level of task chains and also for transformation flows. A scheduled transformation flow uses the default value of the input parameter. Input parameters defined in transformation flows can be used in operators within the transformation flow, except for the Python operation in Apache Spark runtime.

A transformation flow executed as part of a task chain receives input parameters from the task chain. This will allow for more flexible usage of task chains and even nested task chains.

â¡ï¸  Creating a Transformation Flow

â¡ï¸  Creating Input Parameters in Task Chains

 

Email notification in Replication Flows

You can setup email notifications to stay informed when individual replication objects fail in a running replication flow. From both the Replication Flow editor or the Flows monitor, you can setup an email notification for failures of an individual object in a replication flow.

â¡ï¸  Configure Email Notification for Replication Flow Failure at Object Level

â¡ï¸  Working With Existing Replication Flow Runs

 

Fiscal Time Dimension

When creating a time dimension view, you now have the option for dimension type Standard and Fiscal Time. You use the new Fiscal Time dimension type to model your fiscal time periods and the columns that define their starts and ends. When you add a fiscal time dimension to an analytic model, a Fiscal Variant variable is created for this dimension. The variable can then be handled like any other variable. Its data type is derived from the fiscal variance column from the fiscal time dimension.

â¡ï¸  More information

 

Structure Support for Analytic Models

In order to create restrictions and calculations across all measures of an analytic model, you can create structures. Structures help you to save time and ensure consistency in your calculations, as you donâ€™t need to create a formula/calculation for each measure. In the data preview, the structure members are displayed in their own section. When you use a structure member in the drill-down of a preview, the restriction and calculations defined in the structure member will be applied to each measure. Structures can also be used and enhanced in SAP Analytics Cloud. When the analytic model has measures and at least one structure you need to define how the calculations should be prioritized.

â¡ï¸  More information

entry.title: Parameterized Task Chains: What You Can and Canâ€™t Do
entry.content:
Recently, the ability to use parameters in Task Chains was added ... a long-awaited feature for many of us. But what exactly can we do with parameters in Task Chains, and what are the limitations?

â„¹ï¸Allowed Actions in Task Chains

Task Chains let us execute tasks in a controlled way, whether in parallel, sequentially, or a mix of both. The actions we can perform include:

  • Executing a Task Chain
  • Executing a Data Flow
  • Executing a Transformation Flow
  • Creating/Deleting persistence of a View
  • API Task: calling HTTP service (POST, PUT)
  • Notification Task (to send email)
  • Call BW Process Chain
  • Call SQL Script Procedures

However, only some of these actions support parameter usage within a Task Chain:

  • âœ”ï¸ Executing a Task Chain
  • âœ”ï¸ Executing a Transformation Flow

 

â„¹ï¸ Restrictions when using parameters in Task Chains

These objects can be defined with parameters, but we cannot pass parameters from the Task Chain to these objects directly:

  • âŒExecuting a Data Flow
  • âŒ Creating/Deleting persistence of a View

If we add these parameterized objects to a Task Chain, they will only work if their parameters have default values set. We wonâ€™t be able to change them dynamically, but at least we can execute them from within a Task Chain.
If the default parameter is not set, weâ€™ll see an error when adding them to the Task Chain

That said, we can pass parameters to a view if itâ€™s used inside a Transformation Flow. The parameter is first passed to the Transformation Flow, which then passes it to the view.

 

ğŸ”How Does It Work?

Itâ€™s actually quite simple. In the Task Chain, you define the necessary input parameters (you can have multiple inputs if needed) and assign them a value or leave them blank, which will be treated as an empty string.

Thereâ€™s no data type enforcement, no length restrictions, and no functions involved ... all parameters are treated as String value.

Now we add our tasks to the Task Chain. If those tasks support parameters under this new functionality, youâ€™ll see an option to assign values to them.

You can either set a fixed value or map the Task Chainâ€™s input parameter to pass the value dynamically.

If the parameter isnâ€™t supported, you wonâ€™t see any option to assign a value or link the parameter. Hereâ€™s an example of a Data Flow defined with a parameter (with a default value), but without the option to map the Task Chain Input Parameter or assign a value.

And thatâ€™s it ! ... once you run the Task Chain, it will use the values defined in the Input Parameters. If you need to run it with different values, just update them and execute.

ğŸš€ Why This Matters

This new functionality is a major step forward in building smarter and more advanced flows. Hopefully, weâ€™ll soon see features like a global variable repository, the ability to pass those values into parameters, use functions, or derive values from views ... all of which would make the system even more powerful.

entry.title: SAP TechEd Berlin 2025: SAP Business Data Cloud: Data products, master data, governance
entry.content:
Dear Data-Enthusiasts!

Are you still unsure how your data management approach can benefit of SAP Business Data Cloud, what data products are, and which advantages SAP-managed data products bring?

Then you might want to attend our session SAP Business Data Cloud: Data products, master data, and governance (DA100) at SAP TechEd in Berlin on Tuesday, Nov 4 at 9:30 AM.

Besides the questions above, we will also discuss the role of SAP Master Data Governance and how to use it for improved data quality, analytics, and AI.

We are Florian Neukirch @FlorianN and Andreas Seifried @AndreasSeifried, looking forward meeting you during and after our lecture!

Florian is a Senior Product Management Specialist for SAP BDC&I. His focus is on Data Products, Catalog, Marketplace and Data Product Governance. Florian started his career at SAP in Solution Management and has taken over several roles in the SAP BDC&I organization since then.

Andreas is a product manager for SAP Master Data Governance and is engaged in shaping SAPâ€™s portfolio for data management since he joined the development organization in 2004. Andreas started at SAP as a technology consultant in 2001, when he helped organizations all over the world to solve their data and process integration challenges.

We will introduce you to the concept of data products and explore how SAP-managed data products can enhance your data architecture. We'll delve into the significance of master data for analytics, processes, and AI, and discuss upcoming features like the data product studio.

Other related sessions that we recommend:

  • DA203 | SAP Business Data Cloud: The path forward for SAP Business Warehouse by @kpsauer and @kurzdo93 
  • DA266 | Operationalizing AI with SAP Databricks in SAP Business Data Cloud by @san_tran 

Related community topic pages:

SAP Master Data Governance | SAP Community

SAP Business Data Cloud | SAP Community

SAP Datasphere | SAP Community

Looking forward to seeing you in Berlin!

Florian and Andreas

 

Now letâ€™s hear from you:

  • What are your experiences with SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP Master Data Governance?
  • Is it valid to have distinct views on (generic) data management and master data management? What are the reasons?

Please add your thoughts as comments to this blog. Thanks!

entry.title: Implementing SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management â€“ Part 2 (Technical Deep Dive)
entry.content:
In Part 1, of this series, we explored how SAPâ€¯Emarsysâ€¯Loyaltyâ€¯Management addresses modernâ€loyalty demands by going far beyond traditional point-schemes. We reviewed how loyalty programs are evolving into personalised, omnichannel experiencesâ€”and how Emarsys enables brands to design tiers, define actions and rewards, unify customer profiles across touchpoints, and engage members through highly relevant communications.

With that foundational business and functional outlook established, this article now moves into the technical implementation journey, explaining how the architecture, integrations and processes come together to make these business capabilities operational.

 

Prerequisites

To successfully implement SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management, ensure the following components and configurations are in place across the connected SAP landscape.

  SAP Emarsys and Loyalty

  • Unique Identifier for contacts
  • Smart Insight setup
  • Automation program to create and assign Loyalty HashID
  • Loyalty plan configuration (tiers, actions, and benefits)
  • Voucher setup (optional)
  • Loyalty Wallet (standard SDK-based or custom via Loyalty APIs)
  • Automation program to trigger Webhook on loyalty point confirmation events

   SAP S/4HANA

  • Sales data posting integration
  • GL accounts and controlling objects
  • Settlement and clearing logic
  • REST APIs for financial posting for the accruals and redemption scenario

 

Technical Architecture

 

 

Customer Registration and Loyalty Onboarding

Customer registration and loyalty onboarding begin when users join the program to enjoy rewards from their purchases and activities.
New customers can enrol during registration, while existing customers can join the program anytime. For both scenarios, a unique HashID must be generated and assigned to their record before enrolment.

The onboarding process can be initiated across mobile apps, websites, or POS systems.

Typically, SAP Sales Cloud or SAP S/4HANA act as the primary sources of customer data, which are then replicated to SAP Emarsys via SAP CPI.

When a new contact is registered, the record is first created in Sales Cloud or S/4HANA and then replicated to Emarsys. Once created, an automation program generates a HashID and stores it in a custom field at the contact level. Afterward, a Join API call is triggered to add the contact to the relevant Loyalty Plan.

For existing customers who join the loyalty program later, ensure that their HashID is already generated before executing the Join API call.

 

 

Points Accrual

The points accrual process enables customers to earn loyalty points and benefits based on their purchases and other qualifying activities. For purchase-based accruals, sales data flows from SAP S/4HANA (or ERP) to Smart Insight and then to Emarsys Loyalty, where points and benefits are automatically calculated according to the customerâ€™s plan and tier.

Once points are confirmed, they are sent back to SAP S/4HANA for financial posting, ensuring accounting accuracy.

S/4HANA periodically sends sales transaction data to Emarsys through a tenant-specific Sales Data Load URL found under Predict â†’ Data Sources â†’ Sales Data in Emarsys. Once Emarsys receives the data, it calculates points based on the predefined logic.

An automation program triggers a webhook on the loyalty_points_from_purchase_confirmed event, which calls a CPI endpoint. This endpoint posts accrual entries in SAP S/4HANA, crediting customer accounts and updating liability GLs as per company-specific financial configurations.

 

 

Points Redemption

At checkout, customers can redeem their earned loyalty points either by paying directly with points or by using a voucher. Redemption can be initiated via mobile apps or websites during a purchase.

If the customer chooses to pay directly with points, the Remove Points API is called to deduct the required amount from their balance. A â€œPoints Removedâ€ activity is automatically recorded in their Emarsys profile.

Alternatively, customers can claim a voucher using the Claim Voucher API. Once the voucher code is generated, it can be applied at checkout. When a voucher is redeemed, the equivalent points are deducted, and a â€œPoints Redeemedâ€ activity is logged in Emarsys.

The financial postings for redemptions are handled by the respective sales channel (web, mobile, or POS) and then pushed to SAP S/4HANA via CPI to ensure accurate accounting entries.

 

 

Loyalty Segmentation, Personalization, and Campaigns

Effective segmentation and personalization are key to increasing engagement and retention. SAP Emarsys enables marketers to create segments using relational data templates, combining loyalty attributes (tier, points, activity type, or benefits) with contact and behavioral data.

The relational data connection can be setup easily by referring the help link â€œ Setting up Loyalty RDS connectionâ€ and templates can be setup as mentioned in the link  â€œ Setting up Loyalty segment templatesâ€

These segments can be used across multiple campaign channels, including email, SMS, push, and web. Personalization tokens dynamically adapt campaign messages to show details such as the customerâ€™s name, tier, available points, or next reward milestone.

 

  Personalization and Campaign Execution

  Once segments are built, they can be used across multiple channels â€” email, SMS, push notifications, or web campaigns.
  Using personalization tokens, each campaign message can dynamically adapt to display the customerâ€™s name, tier, available points, or next reward milestone, delivering a truly personalized experience.

  SAP Emarsys offers prebuilt email template blocks designed for loyalty-related communications. Upon activation of a loyalty plan, the system automatically generates the relevant loyalty tokens. Furthermore, whenever a new Action or voucher is created, corresponding personalization tokens are generated by default.

  By blending loyalty data with Emarsys campaign automation, businesses can drive:

  • Higher engagement through relevant messaging
  • Increased redemption and repeat purchase rates
  • Stronger customer retention and satisfaction
     

 

 

Loyalty Reports and Dashboards

Analytics play a critical role in measuring loyalty program performance. SAP Emarsys publishes loyalty data to Google Cloud Platform through Open Data Views. These can be connected to SAP Datasphere using the Remote Table option for near real-time data access.

Within SAP Datasphere, organizations can model data, define KPIs (such as Total Points Accrued vs. Redeemed or Active Members by Tier), and then visualize insights using SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) dashboards.

This seamless data flow â€” from Emarsys to GCP, Datasphere, and SAC â€” provides real-time visibility into loyalty KPIs, helping businesses make data-driven decisions and optimize customer engagement strategies.

 

References:

  • List of All Public API Endpoints
  • Smart Insight Settings
  • Loyalty Implementation & Activation
  • Loyalty Tactics
  • Relational Data
  • Creating Segments
  • Personalization
  • Automation Programs

 

Summary

In Part 2, we explored the technical implementation journey of SAP Emarsys Loyalty Management â€” covering end-to-end integration, automation flows, financial postings, customer service enablement, campaign personalization, and analytical insights through SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud.

Stay tuned for Part 3, where we will focus on Customer Service and Support Scenarios in greater detail.

Co-Authors:  @sandeepmkh(Sandeep Kulkarni) and @lokeshla (Lokesh Lakhondae)

entry.title: Join the Data and Analytics Value Map on SAP Community
entry.content:
SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps have moved to SAP Community. Join us now in the SAP Community Groups to stay up to date and informed on the SAP Enterprise Support portfolio for Data and Analytics, ranging from Expert-guided implementation (EGI) sessions, Continuous Quality Check (CQC) services, E-learnings, SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council pilot programs and more.

The Data and Analytics Value Map provides guidance for solutions including SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, SAP Business Warehouse, SAP HANA Cloud, SAP Databricks, as well as SAP BusinessObjects. To see our new look in the SAP Community, watch the short SAP video (1 min, 30): SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps on SAP Community

 

How to Access

  • To access the SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps Group, you must login to SAP Community with an S-user ID or a Universal ID
  • Navigate to us via the tab â€œGroupsâ€, then â€œCustomer Only Groupsâ€ or via our dedicated page: SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps

  • Once in the SAP Enterprise Support Value Maps Group, select the Data and Analytics Value Map and click â€œJoin Groupâ€
  • Expand the â€œOptionsâ€ button and click â€œSubscribeâ€ to get email notifications of activity within the group
  • Why join and subscribe? To set customization preferences, get notifications, participate in the group and have a better user experience

 

Blog Posts

We will continue to post blogs to let you know about availability of new and updated content in the SAP Enterprise Support portfolio, such as new E-Learnings, events taking place, best practices, and other relevant information for the Data and Analytics topic.

 

Knowledge Base

Our Knowledge Base is a collection of documents, which provide both foundational information and in-depth guidance for SAP Data and Analytics topics including SAP Business Data Cloud. These focused documents organize the Expert-guided implementation (EGI) sessions, Continuous Quality Check (CQC) services, E-learnings, best practices, and more by topic. Making it easier for you to see in one place the SAP Enterprise Support offerings by topic and/or solution area. Here are three Knowledge Base directories to bookmark within the Data and Analytics Value Map:   

  • SAP Business Data Cloud Directory
  • SAP Data Warehousing Directory
  • SAP BusinessObjects BI 2025 Directory

 

Q&A

Use the Q&A section to ask us questions or find questions that have already been answered. For example, maybe you need guidance on how to find best practices and make use of the SAP Enterprise Support offerings for your project such as a BW modernization in SAP Business Data Cloud. The following could be relevant for you: 

  • EGI for SAP BW Modernization with SAP Business Data Cloud
  • CQC for Private Cloud Go-Live 
  • CQC for Implementation
  • CQC Technical Performance Optimization (TPO)
  • CQC Business Process Performance Optimization (BPPO)
  • CQC for Security Optimization
  • CQC for Data Volume Management

Full details are in the Knowledge Base SAP BW Modernization with Foundational Support

 

Events

The monthly EGI schedule will be populated here giving details of the planned EGI topics, dates, time, regions and languages.

 

Request a Call

Request a call with one of our topic experts to connect with the right content and resources.

 

LIVE SESSIONS on SAP Enterprise Support value maps â€“ Our Move to SAP Community

Join this live session on October 22, 2025, to learn more, where we will demo SAP Enterprise Support value maps on SAP Community. ğŸ”— Link to join / Watch Replay

 
Enhance Your SAP Experience with Value Maps 

SAP Enterprise Support offers additional resources to help you drive innovation. SAP Enterprise Support value maps provide expert-led resources, tailored recommendations, and advisory services - all included in your SAP cloud subscription. Get started today:

  • One-time sign up for SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support, using a valid S-User ID (please allow up to 2 hours for processing)
  • Access SAP Enterprise Support value maps for personalized guidance
  • Request a call with our solution area experts for tailored advice

Value Maps are part of SAP Enterprise Support commitment to your success. Visit the SAP Enterprise Support value maps landing page to explore our range of topics and start engaging with us today.

 

About the author: 
Caroline Sheridan is a Topic Expert for SAP Enterprise Support value maps, specializing in SAP Data and Analytics.â€¯With a tenure of 12 years at SAP, Carolineâ€™s expertise lies in assisting and guiding customers to succeed through SAP Enterprise Support offerings. 

ğŸ’¡Have questions or feedback on this content? Feel free to leave a comment below or submit them in the Q&A section.

entry.title: Launch your Data Science Platform with SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Let's set the architecture.

Within SAP Business Data Cloud we will use SAP Datasphere and SAP Business Data Cloud. Note that SAP Databricks runs on its own Object Store. This is not the same object store that could be activated in SAP Datasphere. We will not activate an Object Store (BDC Object Store) for this case.  You can do that. This means, that you will benefit from Data Products (SAP and Customer managed). But as of today you will lose semantics. Therefore we will go for another approach this time. Make sure to check which approach might be best for you.

 

  • 1. Step: Activate SAP Datasphere and SAP Databricks. If you already have a Datasphere (activated before 2025) and you want it to be in your BDC formation, please make sure to contact your BDC account executive.
  • 2. Step: Within SAP Datasphere create a space (HANA Cloud not Hana Data Lake Files)
  • 3. Step: Within this space, create a view which is exposed for consumption. Note that you have to create a view. Tables (also remote tables) cannot be exposed

  • 4. Step: Create a database user 

  • 5. Step Open SAP Databricks
  • 6. Step Open a Workbook and connect it to a running Cluster 
  • 7. Step Insert the following to find your Clusters IP Address
%pip install fedml-databricks --no-cache-dir --upgrade --force-reinstall from fedml_databricks import DbConnection,predict 
import numpy as np 
import pandas as pd 
import json 
import socket 

hostname = socket.gethostname() ip_address = socket.gethostbyname(hostname) display({"Cluster Hostname": hostname, "Cluster IP Address": ip_address})â€‹
  • 8. Step: In SAP Datasphere whitelist the IP Address
  • 9. Step: Create personal token in SAP Databricks
  • 10. Step: Create Scope
  • 11. Step: Create Secret (enter Credentials from SAP Datasphere Database User)
  • 12. Step: Establish Connection with Secret
pip install hana-ml
from hana_ml.dataframe import ConnectionContext
conn = dataframe.ConnectionContext(address='',
                                   port=443, 
                                   user='', 
                                   password='' 
                                  )
conn.connection.isconnected()
  • 13. Step: Connect to view 
df_remote = hana_conn.table('<yourexposedview>', schema='<yourspaceschema>')â€‹

Congrats! You now can perform predictions based on your data in SAP Datashere. You can return the data to SAP Datasphere as HANA Table.
